w my fave little car the P1 vs GT40 on SB. I kept on losing a lot of +50pi matchups, those you have to hit all the perfects that you want, and maybe miss a few intentionally, depending on the opponent and track

WRITING.TITLE: RS200 race advice?
WRITING.TEXT: Running RS200 vs RS200 +25pi on Bayside Rivals, nose level w rear bumper of AI car, 2/3 of the way thru the tunnel I hit my double boost, burnout finished 1/3 up the ramp. AI car started double boost at ramp start. I finish the jump first, thinking OK I #8217;m good, then the AI car blows by me in the slo mo sequence like I #8217;m standing still, wins by like 3 lengths. So RS200 owners, how do you run on Bayside? Most cars I double boost ASAP (once it #8217;s full) after the tire screeching on turn 3 is done (due to the sketch landings for so many cars). Is there benefit on some cars to wait for later ( burn thru the jump and into the landing?)?

Classic Fairlady not all that bad, I haven #8217;t leveled up mine but running it in Rivals it #8217;s a middling+ performer. Even tho RS200 is usually a good rivals target I #8217;ve lost to it several times in the final slo mo sequence. Final straight, at their rear bumper or slightly ahead, double boost, home fre... what the f? It #8217;s like it has a magic triple boost. The 914/6 the same. Most of the time you can stomp on it, but if you ran a sloppy race and it #8217;s anywhere close at the end, magical finishing speed. I need to look at perf profile, even tho not accurate it gives s sense of how the devs intend that car to run, so a car with bad acceleration or launch but ok top speed can make you pay for sloppy racing at the finish. The key is running clean enough to keep on building gap after every turn.

Sorry please explain differently. On iOS there #8217;s no carryover on opponent launch between races that I can tell. So one race good. Another slow, etc. rather only reliable thing is they never? perfect launch. DD you can mess with the AI car since it #8217;s short even with bad performance you can get in striking distance. In half decent turning cars early gassing turn 3 pays off in close races, you can push the AI car up to the curb if you got the inside line on the turn

WRITING.TITLE: Your fave Rivals targets?
WRITING.TEXT: Muscle- retro cobra R, Gto Street- skyline II, Silvia, Focus Classic- 914/6, 911, ZR1, gto Sports - RS200, 370z, 914/6, RS200 Super - GT40, countach, Ford GT, 73 amp; 95 911 Rare- RS200, focus, GT Epic- Skyline II, GT40 These are also the cars I run with the smallest pi differential when driving them in rivals ( well I don #8217;t have skyline II or GT40 yet.). RS200 amp; Focus especially nerve wracking, no lead feels safe. Some are safer to run against than others, GT amp; ZR1 on the bubble. I #8217;ve lost to those running OKish races but maybe too big a PI differential (+35ish is my usual #8220;good enough, let #8217;s rumble #8221; threshold)
That was super day.

On DD3 sometimes you #8217;re behind, and even a 2nd perfect won #8217;t get you a double boost before 3/4 of the straight done, too late. Early gas if you #8217;re getting passed on the outside can shove AI car to the curb, or block it for a second, you keep the lead, and a single boost ( all you will have anyway) enough to win. Bayside 2 same deal- while hovering/ sliding/ waiting for the perfect gas you #8217;re getting passed. Learn when/ how to trade a half boost for position. How early you can get away with highly car amp; corner dependent

Acura? It would be funny to have a Tesla too. No rev sounds. Just an insane start amp; accel out of corners. Then in every accel zone NO GAS! NO GAS! And then the turbo meter would be a battery or capacitor symbol instead. Somewhat limited in top end speed so it would be tops in DD, OKish in Bayside, and be hanging on for dear life in the long straights of SB.

Yeah rs200, focus, cobra are all very good turners so early gas works great for those I think for them between that and how anemic their boosts are it pays to early gas to get outta a corner. In DD2 the other day I was waiting for my perfect gas and the AI GTR got all up my rear taking me near 45deg sideways. Someone advised never boost before Bay1 save it for a double but I get taken wide there so often by waiting, not sure on that. On a perfect start amp; brake you can jet outta there early, but even on a good start maybe that makes sense. You #8217;ll be 1/3 downhill before your double boost is ready, but knocked wide same issue, still sliding for that long, or wasting part of your boost if you hit it before sliding is done

Agree F1 is fast, just sucks at turns. P1 though the launch is chancy (mash and hold the INSTANT you see the 2 countdown, before its big) WOW. A+ Launch, A- turns, A speed. Senna feels like a slightly better Z06. A-launch A turns A- speed
And don #8217;t log in on the mobile before the PC version is closed (it will let you sign in and override) else next time on PC you have to run the intro races again, so annoying.

The 370z like the Mustang GT I feel are adequate cars with tame launches if that #8217;s your priority. 370z was my primary modern sports ( more due to Forza lottery luck than standout performance ) before I got the Z06, then was considering leveling up past the low 500s when it hit 4*. But then my McL 570s hit 4* with help of a double down offer, and the Z06 became spotlight car so I got that to 4* too. I personally chose the 570s over the 370z since it felt like it had better acceleration although I didn #8217;t do any systematic testing of lap times. In Rivals I feel I do better against 370z than vs Fairlady Z generally.

Agree, sometimes just gotta go with what the card spin lottery gets you to 4* first. Skyline II amp; focus both great launches but weak on straight speed. You need one modern amp; one classic at pretty high PI in each class to advance in story, and one or 2 retros for generic upgrade path and spotlight events. Some class upgrades events also need a high retro in the uptake and brake events, but worry about that once you #8217;re in the mid 500s. Of what you show, Boss 302 amp; Charger Hellcat decent for muscle. Some like charger RT for classic Z06 amp; stingray good sports. Z06 may get stuck at 3* max of 585 until it comes back in spotlight, but good to have a high PI epic like that until you get a 4* common or rare to surpass it. Street 2008 M3 is good modern if you have it at 3*+, for classics, 2002 turbo, skyline, escort popular with different people. Capri has rough launch but good speed. Super your GTR not bad. For classic I like Miura but many prefer 904. Aside from lottery luck, a lot is personal taste- you want more top speed, or easier perfect turns. So practice on early story events with opponent difficulty set at +20-30pi over your cars and see what you like running with, and hate running against, and that gives hints on what cars you might want to upgrade

F1 is a totally crap turner. Bayside turn 1 it hovers/drifts forever waiting for the perfect gas, then opponent car has caught up and shoves you to the wall. If you can perfect start, perfect brake, then one wheel length before yellow zone, early gas it. On the early gas of Bayside 2, you have to be conservative, gassing before half thru red zone you're into the outside curb pretty hard and losing speed, only do super early if you're on the turn inside and behind opp , you'll sideswipe opp, so although you lose speed they definitely do too. DD F1 is not great either since that's nearly all turns. If I manage a perfect start and perfect brake, I'll try for the perfect gas but biasing toward the early side turn 1. If you miss, no big deal, already full on boost. You're usually on left side after turn 2, then see where opp is relative. If way behind I'll single boost to get inside track turn 3. If close-ish I wait cross my fingers and hope they start to do a right side pass. If so after a perfect brake you'll be around 1.75boost or higher and if on the inside track of the turn you can play it by ear. If before end of red zone opp has gotten ahead, try and early gas once their rear wheel/bumper is level w/ your nose, and you'll shove them up the curb. Same tactic if you burned the single boost but they still managed an outside pass using a double. If after your brake you're near/over 1boost but below 1.3 then try and optimize for the shove rather than the boost. The only exception might be against Focus, RS200, or SkylineII with super weak double boosts. Otherwise, by the time you've finished the perfecting the gas they're 1/3 of the way down the stretch and even a double boost won't catch you up. Stingray 427 is similar to F1, decent speed but wait forever to perfect gas, and kinda wide sliding on turns. Yesterday on DD3 I had the inside corner, 0.9 boost after the brake, and opp was half length ahead (my nose just behind driver door) entering gas zone while I was still in red, waiting. Opted to gas then, shoved it up the curb, and we were running even for a fraction of a second, saw my boost was at 1.1, so took it right then. They ran out of curb and had to tuck in behind me, and I held on. A different time I waited too long, and they jumped off the curb in front of me. Hard to know what opp boost level was so that could have been the difference, but if they're up the curb, grab the lead while you can.

Yeah a bit surprised on the choice of Focus. In Rivals it seems super slow, no lead is safe. Does it act more nicely in story/upgrade/spotlight? Do you try for race tactics other than double perfects (when I run it in rivals it seems pretty robust to super early gassing- no half boost but you're exiting turns way early)? Still even with that I usually lose with Focus in Rivals, even vs +20PI (aside from another Focus). AI does seem to cut some slack. Maybe it's selective memory, but the times I too much gas the start feels like proportionally more often the AI does the same (at least more than usual).

Didn #8217;t know how to unlock upgrade events until nearly two weeks in, but got super lucky on last day of McL event. 3 Senna copies for 700g in spins! P1 is still my favorite car to not autorace tho.
Currently a lot of generic brake parts on order (3 per day)

Not a single epic? Z06 was spotlight maybe a month ago. Were you not playing yet then? And viper last week, hard not to get a single copy in the week. Even if you only dominate spotlight 1 daily that #8217;s 4 spins per week, add a couple gold spins and it #8217;s like 70% odds. Or you mean none at 4* yet. That I could see
While everyone else sleeps (event starts 9pm Pacific USA), I get to slip ahead for a brief moment. By midday I should be back in the mid 100 range #128523;

They allow multi image posts now so slide it to see... 323ti at 606pi. No Senna? Did you not have enough gold in McL event? I had to buy my 1st (200g), same for my P1. 200g for my 2nd P1, so I got greedy, 900g for the next 2, then hit a cold streak- 500g more to stay stuck at 3.75*. It runs the same speed as a 3.0* copy apparently.

P1 you have to mash gas the INSTANT the 2 countdown shows, like its small and barely turned gray. No cash in, just judiciously using game gold. Foolishly(?) spent 850g for 10x spotlight cards like 2-3 weeks in, altho it did populate my garage better early on . After that saved gold until McL event. I bought my first McL the P1 after realizing I couldn #8217;t touch half the McL event board without at least 1, tho by the time I leveled it up to usable range they rearranged the format and took a few more days of tune amp; upgrade. Still, with it stuck at 519pi (waiting for super upgrade day) I could beat the 550/560 McLs daily, so then I knew it was a special car.

Ok, but I was squeezing some spotlight 2 amp;3 I guess. If you can dominate spotlight 1, you can usually win at least 1 race in spotlight 2 with 2 cars/6 tries, grab some chips amp; quit. Spotlight 3 the first chips are free, just grab amp; quit.
Hah you #8217;re much more likely to stay top 20 given 9 hrs to go vs 20some

WRITING.TITLE: Did they beef up the Skyline II in Rivals?
WRITING.TEXT: Classic Escort 470pi vs Skyline II 505pi on South Beach, I'd run a pretty poor race to that point, with the Nissan boosting \~3 seconds before turn 3 for the lead. So I do the perfect brake very early gas thing, passing it by 2 lengths just outside turn 3, then double boost down the stretch. I think OK whew that was close, and then closing on the finish, slo-mo kicks in and the Skyline is boosting past, finishing 1 length ahead. 1. Classic Escort is not in my regular usage rotation, so is it just slow on straights? 2. Or have they boosted the performance of some Epics like the Skyline that were previously over-crippled? 3. Or is it just the inevitable outcome of a poorly run race up to that point (happened to me prior vs a Focus on SB) Part of me is guessing 3. If you run well enough in the front of the race, you're not anywhere close enough to notice the closing speeds of the Focus/Skyline/other seemingly slow cars, e.g. with poor acceleration but middling to good top speed. But if you are still in contact at the end, watch out. But others noticing overperforming previously really horrid epics makes me think 2 is not out of the question as well.

Sort of feel I have to play the hand I #8217;m dealt, I was level 22 before I got my first 2* M3, now plodding behind at 3.5*. I have a few common streets at 4* but none really stand out enough to swap. No Senna at spin 9! That #8217;s a special class of the 1%. Thankfully the worst I #8217;ve seen is a win on spin 8 (6 card misses on last days of the viper spotlight). Had to add 2 gold spins to get copy 5 and 4* it. Running the viper at 470pi in Rivals tho, seems really slow on the straights, I lost with it. So I tried taking on a +25pi viper, and lost to it. Not sure if I should level it up, doubt it can top my Z06 or 570s even if brought up to 600pi, neither of those ever felt sluggish at low PI.

Do you try for the double perfect on SB 3 then, or half perfect it, early gas out, take the single and a late single. In my case I was at 1.7 boost exiting SB3 with the early gas, passed the Skyline a second later, double boosted 2 seconds later, starting my countdown to finish.. 5, 4, 3.... and 3seconds after my burnout done the slo mo kicked in where I got passed (2, 1...) I do know if your double boost will only be ready to start with lt;5 sec left you #8217;re probably better off taking the 2 singles on SB for sure. DD and Bayside tho there are times a double boost that started mid backstretch DD or mid tunnel bayside got the win from behind.

In order of pref I like the Miura most, but charger amp; stingray had more recent spotlights + American classics event and thus got upgrades sooner, + the rare/common gap. Feel the stingray is least reliable or less special vs possible opponents. I had 300SL as sports classic leader prior, but is stalled at 3.75*, lacking recent spotlight. Plus the bayside landings were getting worse at high pi on the 300sl.
Interesting, I #8217;ll try and run a focus similar next time I need to on rivals. Do you run other cars on SB that way? Many don #8217;t handle very early gas that well

WRITING.TITLE: PSA: Remember how to do math on Rivals

WRITING.TEXT: Doing retro Rivals today, I forgot the ginormous PI gap I have in my retro line up. Pull a 623pi Rs200, figure 23+ my SVT Cobra R is 6 below 500 = 29pi , I can swing that. RS200 rockets off, always pulling away. Hmm ok did they beef it up a lot? Shake it off, get a matchup vs 630pi Evo II, 30-05 = 25, my Countach should handle that right? With perf launch still in touch to turn 1 on SB but then ever widening gap and the Evo becomes a tiny dot. Uh yeah 630 minus FIVE-05 is 125pi difference, not 25. 129pi on the prior... DOH! So discombobulated that I lost the next match F1 at 585pi vs another Rs200 at 622pi on DD. DD is probably the worst place for that matchup but still usually totally winnable. Some days you should probably have stayed in bed, or at least gotten a 2nd coffee.

Crank through story. That #8217;s how I tried to scrape together gold as the McL event was wrapping. 10g per event finished, 20g to dominate. 20g per part finished, 50g dominated. The every 4 hr free currency awards sometimes give gold. Supposed to be 10%. If you time exactly, skip 1 per day (one right before bed, sleep 8 hrs. 1 right when you get up) maybe 1 win per 2 days. Not fast but it #8217;s something. Hitting up the upgrade events and doing the daily challenge tho are probably the most energy efficient way to get free spins. save your gold for double down offers on rare or common cars (offered when you hit 3.75*, take it and you #8217;re instantly 4*). Maybe on an epic too if not in a spotlight car. If spotlight. For 700g you can buy 7 spotlight spins and every epic win is 3* copy. Rare and common spotlight wins are often 2*, so 400g for a guaranteed 3* copy of a rare is better than buying 5 spins at 85g each

I would crank that Charger hellcat and RT up to 600ish pi since they #8217;re at 4* already. Easy autorace workhorses for non-restricted races. Miura get that up to 600ish too. If you #8217;ve got any non upgraded common or rare modern super cars approaching or at 4* see how you like running them vs +20pi opponents, as compared to Ford GT. I spam Ep112 for challenge cards (good as a test track)- if set to floating max difficulty 4 (when your car is gt;20pi above difficulty 3) it auto sets to your cars pi+10-20. 3 races = 5 challenge cards, all of them level 3 tuning kits, and ~300CR on average. Modern sports your 720s more likely to 4* before your Z06. If you have a 570s at 3.5* or higher, that might hit 4* even sooner. I think all of those drive decent. Classic sports 300SL not bad except horrible slider on Bayside end. Street modern I like C32 over Focus. I never upgraded Focus over 500, it feels lacking in speed for Bayside or SB. 2008 M3 better than either of them. Street classic escort is OK. I would take at least one retro to high 500pi, for spotlight and upgrade events. Unless you really like how Silvia K drives, 1991 M3 I think is better, and will soon be 4* too. Like the Focus, RS200 nearly no lead feels safe

Yes, in case I wasn #8217;t clear, don #8217;t take the double down on Epic cars during its spotlight or special event where you can buy a spin for 100g. 7 spins in an epic spotlight event gets you shots at other cars, and your epic win is always 3*, well over 70%cumulative odds by spin 7. Outside its event though, could be a while before you see it again. Rare or common cars however, although bought spotlight spins guarantee the car within 10, more than half the time they are 2* and you may spend the same or more gold (250g or 400g for common or rare respectively) and still be short of 4*. But don #8217;t take every double down (including epics), only the cars you really like and want to promote to really high PI. Sometimes you later regret a choice, that #8217;s Ok. But if you #8217;re not changing your mind every week you have enough time to build back enough for the next double down or spotlight where you need some gold. Personally I never take the double down making the 3.25* into 3.5 only the 3.75* to 4. You may still wait forever at 3.5* for that next copy.

I NEVER spend gold on energy packs. Just decide on your priorities. Like most people class upgrade usually top priority unless its a car I REALLY want in spotlight. You can get lots of car spins from class upgrade = tuning kits amp; CR amp; more spin chips for any dupes you get, or missing cars to fill your garage. In terms of NRG burned per car spin, usually better than spotlight. I'm never quite sure if dominating a class upgrade event is worth it, nearly triple the energy for a 2nd part, and and the 3rd run through there's not much left to pick up in spin chips or tuning kits. If you're in a hurry to get certain class parts though I guess what other choice is there, wait another half week? If I've got cars waiting for generic parts to supplement class parts for upgrade I'll usually run that before spotlight. Dominating if I need triples or more (typical for intakes and brakes at higher upgrade levels- but early on you mostly need tons of exhausts for various cars). Otherwise I'll pick a single run thru path that gets the biggest combo of CR, wrenches, amp; upgrade chips, or the shortest one that will get me the part I want for minimal energy. Spotlight I'll run or do last depending on if it's not a car I like/want. Spotlight dominating an event gives you triple more victory chips, so for example if you can dominate event 3 you get way more points than you would from single runs through spotlight event 2 and 1. Likewise dominating 2 better than single runs through 1 2 3 I think, although I haven't tallied exactly. Always do the daily challenge. Essentially a free premium card for minimal additional effort. Sometimes it's the same class as upgrade event for the day. Even if not, I just spam Ep112 with the car class in question (or if win with a car in each class, use the 3 classes not in the upgrade event of the day), or do it in generic upgrade. You can also work in your +10pi or perfect brake quotas that way too if you haven't met it in the upgrade or other events.

Autorace depends. I'll manually race if I have to but to get around to other life stuff I often autorace. But yeah if I have to burn up a real world minute for a race (or out of boredom) I'll set it to difficulty 4 for more challenge packs. Last race of a long event string if I'll have to burn wrenches to rerun I'll just set it to autorace. If I blow an early race in a long string I just quit and restart event. After a while you get a sense of which PI gaps you can handle vs which cars even allowing for less than your average performance, and plan accordingly. Yeah this spotlight boost has much better payoff than usual, and super amp; generic parts too, so all rolled in one, so after class upgrade (if a class you want/need) spotlight gets top billing. Still, no generic brakes in this event and that is my major logjam now, a few \~600ish cars between upgrade 9/10/11, so I'm not bothering with spotlight 1 and doing generic upgrade 3 instead.

Car suggestions post stickied on this reddit. But I like the race data sheet to put some real numbers behind it. You can see how various cars do at different PI and enter your own better/best runs with a given car. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1uliYI-CDk5NIgJuuyzogk0N2oiKE6zMzyoxRBVAtmzM/htmlview#gid=0

In this case it tilted in my favor but other times launch smack in middle of green perfect zone gives too much gas or just good. Basically a random launch generator. Another occasional issue is the game on iPad suddenly decides my thumb is not on throttle at all mid race, when I #8217;m pressing moderately hard and not moving my thumb that I know of, I have to wiggle it around and it #8217;ll flicker on and off, by which time the race is lost of course. I guess I should learn to not even try playing on the iPad but nice not having to just look at a little phone screen with my bad eyesight #128541;

Don #8217;t forget the daily challenge, one premium card per day, for usually relatively little effort. Initially some seem tough #8220;win 5 p'races #8221; #8220; beat a +10pi opponent #8221; #8220;perform 5 perfect brakes #8221;. Even dominating spotlight event 1 won #8217;t get you a card each day I think.
Congrats l still don #8217;t have GT40, Spyder, Skyline II, ZL1

I only recently got my 2008 M3 to 3*, now I see why people liked it so much, a super tame launch like the 370z or mustang GT, with decent handling and better top speed. I kinda like the GTR, great launch, but maybe less top end speed than McL P1 or Senna. Seeing as I have those at 3.75 and 4* respectively, even when my GTR hits 4* prob no point in upgrading it. Except maybe to take on higher end rivals.

WRITING.TITLE: Bel Air a decent car?
WRITING.TEXT: Ran into one in rivals (tired of waiting for the #8220;right #8221; Focus or Skyline II to pop up, kept getting +15-20 and +50 versions to run against) running +25pi vs my Retro M3 619pi. DD only got a good launch, and I only half perfected turn 1. Single boost didn #8217;t get me very clear, pushed around the corner again, and my double boost didn #8217;t clear me by enough (maybe still sliding from the corner push?) because as I was waiting for my perfect gas on DD3 it was outside passing me. I was so close to the gas zone I opted to wait, maybe a mistake because after the perfect gas I was at 1.3 boost. Double boost would be too late to be of use, so I single, start gaining, but it single boosts halfway down stretch. My second single ready 3/4 of the way but I #8217;m 2 lengths back at that point, so i only close to its rear bumper by the finish. I suspected the Bel Air not that weak of a car but retro M3 usually my old reliable, and +25 not that big a gap. 2 more perfects (half a boost extra or earlier)and maybe a different outcome, but I #8217;m used to getting away with a bit of slop. Using it in rivals I ran it vs a +35 Focus (with my better street cars I usually try +40-45) and it was easier than I expected so maybe I #8217;ve been misjudging it. Bel Air is still only 3.5* so it #8217;s not going to be in my regular rotation, but I #8217;m giving some more respect now.

Spin lottery gave me a 323ti advancing faster than most. Got stalled at 3.9* for a while, but broke thru to 4* a few weeks back. Good enough, better than the 1 series for sure. E63 and C32 I like to race with/ dislike facing more than the 1 M.

Personal stats are always small counts of examples so it #8217;s hard to say. Unless you have hundreds of players entering their stats it #8217;s hard to know for sure. Like on the McLaren event way more people declaring 0 or 1 for 12 McL on the non guaranteed McL cards (the supposed 20% = 2 or 3 of 12) within their first 15, than the opposite, 4+. Some of it is reporter bias, unhappy people are more vocal. But even a few dozen responding to the poll may be a random skewed sub sample. I was among the unlucky. 0 of 17. 1 at #18. Then in my next 16 I got 4 (25%, a bit better than listed odds). On the last day of event, I gambled with only 900g needing 3 wins to get a 3.25* senna up to 4* (an epic double down needs 700g so I would have to win on Both my 1st amp; 2nd spins to use that). In the end I got 3 copies in 7 spins, way better than listed odds. This week on the Charger SRT spotlight, felt pretty unlucky, wins on spin 5, 2, 5, 6, 9, 4, overall 6 of 31. SRT Already hit 4* so not needing to dominate every event daily. But zero epics among the spins. A few 3* common and rare on other cars (and one of the SRT a 3*). So the wins and misses come very unevenly.

Yeah some of the best cars are rare or epic, but many commons hit well above average. Miura, Cuda, CTSV. And many rares and epics shine initially but fade at higher PI. The bump in maxed out PI at 3* is useful to progress, but then hinders as you wait forever for dupes. Spotlights help but you can #8217;t count on your fave car showing up for weeks, months.

WRITING.TITLE: Design District Dip
WRITING.TEXT: I wish I was quicker on the draw at screenshot capture, or that FS had a replay option (whole race, or at least last turn to finish). DD there #8217;s this little dip right before the finish line. So I have a race pretty much in the bag, driving Senna, and release pedal dunno maybe half second before the line, apparently braking right into the dip, scrape, go 30deg sideways, clip the arch post over the finish line. It ended up as a photo finish win but I was too shocked and amused to get a screenshot in time. A lot of FS is same old same old every race, but I kinda like driving sloppy/on the edge, for the occasional surprise discovery. I #8217;m guessing this wouldn #8217;t happen in any street or muscle car with good ground clearance. Most sports aren #8217;t that low either, right? So maybe only supers, like P1 amp; Senna especially low. Maybe GT?

Personally I like the Cayman gt; CTSV, Miura gt; Cuda, but they #8217;re different classes, and in my garage way different PI, so not possible to time trial on the different tracks. I just know that these are cars I #8217;d rather avoid in Rivals, and don #8217;t mind running with larger PI gaps.

Just for yucks I set up an Excel table (prob could be done in google sheets too) with random numbers generated (0-1) in groups of 50 as rows, if you count up sets with 3 or less hits above 0.9 (=10% odds, or you could count up lt;0.1, same odds) there are quite many. Haven #8217;t worked out how many modern street cards you can rack up per week even if you dominate (or at least get thru next to last race) all the street upgrade events, maybe 5-6? So 20 weeks to get ~100 spins, even odds to score one Skyline II. So totally have come to grips with likelihood of never seeing some of the epics unless or until they spotlight. Even though there are some odds of other epics in spotlight or premium cards, it #8217;s so diluted by other class epics that once you have a few, you #8217;re more likely to get a dupe of an epic you already have vs get a new one.

Attempting to do the Super upgrade 3, i couldn #8217;t get past the 629pi retro race with a 3* F1 on DD. Couldn #8217;t manage a full perfect run so started trying to bump the AI car off line. It does seem to try to avoid getting checked into the wall when it sees you coming in hot with a late brake or super early gas. I gave up after 12 tries (easy to quit and retry as it is the 2nd race in the event).

I think I #8217;ve found out now the repeated slow launch thing does happen on iOS too, just that you can #8217;t reliably come back to it. PC is truly multitasking so a session never closes on its own, whereas on IOS if I go away and do too many other screens, even if I never killed/ terminated the FS session it reopens on the launch screen with the loading bar and everything is reset. So you just have to do it all in one go, no switching to email or phone call or whatever.

I found the Huracan not so bad to drive, slightly less of the wait forever for perfect gas of most other Lambos. For all of those bellyaching about the spotlight choices, wait until they roll out the Retro Cobra R week #128561;

It sounds like it #8217;s by intent then. By constraining to the generic class spins, it lowers the odds of just picking more than one up randomly, so more need for gold when the special events roll around = more potential $. That the McLs are at all available outside the McL event I think is a new thing.

In Star progression that is. I got my first 2* copy at collector level 22 or so. Finally hit 3.75* so took the double down. I guess technically Skyline II is slower yet (0*), although it #8217;s not yet #8220;my #8221; car with 0 copies. I am so itching for that crazy fast launch and underwhelming speed... or not. Maybe for completionist OCD.

Easiest on DD because the turns are tight, and the separation not impossible to close on turns. Any time you get an inside corner you have a shot of late braking or early gassing the AI into a wall/curb/post. On good turning cars only a super early gas will send you wide enough to push out the AI car. I think multiple times I #8217;ve overcommitted to a ramming and the computer read it and dodged by braking hard, kinda like they do in ice hockey to avoid a hard check into the boards. Sometimes on a slow turning car you end up on the receiving end tho. Trying to squeeze out the last 25pts of a perfect gas you #8217;ll get taken out wide by the AI car muscling in as they boost into the turn. So sometimes if the last look back seems kinda tight, I #8217;ll gas a shade early just to get outta the turn before trouble comes barreling in. In Rivals, 25pts missed vs 600+ for losing the race. In story/upgrade/spotlight just get the heck outta there unless the perfect will get you nearly the full boost, or you #8217;re doing it just for practice- same challenge points regardless.

What has slower top speed Focus or skyline II? On your bayside downhill double boost, I assume you did it from top of the hill? If any car can hold on with a no lift bayside 2 turn with a double boost starting from mid downhill ( a triple good launch, brake, gas to start would lead to that) that would be good.

Haha. Cool. Maybe I should try a lite version of that with the Focus. My focus is no longer starting PI ( enough dupes to 4*, plus got it to 460 to Rivals bait opponents for a cluster of 431pi cars. I know for sure it can no lift Bayside 2, whether it can with a single or double boost burning right up to the start of the brake zone another question. Likewise no braking or micro braking turn 1 amp;3, or DD, maybe a Focus/skyline2 strategy for that is brake/ super early gas every turn there with boost mid straight each leg.

Another thought is how well the opposite would work, super late brake and try for perfect gas. For most cars and turns when I barely miss brake late I can swing a perfect gas about 1/3 of the time (close to half on SB 1 amp; 3). But I imagine Focus/Skyline2 could push it to or past the turn apex to very late brake and not totally slide out. On good turning cars I #8217;ve found my attempts to bump out the AI car at DD 3 have sometimes failed due to turning too well inside of them to hit despite early gassing. Trick on those may be to gas even earlier, or super late brake to ensure swinging wide enough to hit. I guess even on races well in hand you can practice, early gas to the point you not quite or barely hit the curb on exit, and if next time there #8217;s a car there, they #8217;ll be doing a bit of curb hopping ;)

Ok, for sure no micro braking bayside turn 1 or 3, out of the question in a Focus at 460pi. I tried both at 45% thru the turn, just before the apex, and ended up flirting with the wall and losing ground. I also had a centenario at 452pi and a Evolution II at 449, and tho the specs bar chart had the centenario at like 6 bars+ on handling and the Focus amp; Evo II @ 4 bars, the actual case was the opposite, all but the slightest early gassing and you #8217;re sliding out everywhere in the Cento. Kinda like a diablo but worse. Focus and Evo II handle a half hood early gas with little drama. Super Early gassing may still pay off in a focus given how anemic it #8217;s single and double boosts are, but I #8217;ll have to try at maybe 75% thru the turn.
How on earth can you drive facing backwards and sideways?! I guess Forza Street is semi driving on rails but the timing would be way off I #8217;m guessing

A crash and a win! Retro M3 prior run this * #165;%^ing Cuda got in the way of my double boost outta DD2, I hung up on its left rear bumper, lifted amp; pushed it 2/3 of the way down leg 2, dropped it back down right before turn DD3, at which point it was ahead and proceeded to win. So next run I was hot for payback, missed in front trying to crunch it coming out of turn 2, and i was back a half length into DD3 so I super early gassed half thru the turn, and it braked/ didn #8217;t gas, and I missed in front again and hit and bounced off the wall. It was at near a dead stop after dodging my crunch. So I had a single boost in the tank, reaccelerated using it, and stayed ahead enough for the win! Maybe I just need to start recording my reckless/wreckfull DD runs regularly, 90%+ end up unremarkable, but some are quite interesting. Who woulda thunk they would program in the possibility to jam under and lift the tail of the opponent?

Right, but the timing on brake and gas zones I wouldn #8217;t be able to guess within the right half second driving looking sideways or backwards. Sure you could get thru missing all the timing but slim/ no chance of keeping up w/ the computer driver. Unless the VR is just a tour mode drive thru, not a race.
Maybe they only fixed up to 9999 or 999... I mean who could possibly have gt;10k right? ;)

A port to Xbox wouldn #8217;t be that hard I imagine, if they made it F2P or very low cost, and maybe add a few features (rear view mirror button or toggle, half boost option). Space bar trick? Was that a rapid redemption option in the old PC version that would speed you through the animation/redeem another sequence? They suggested a Retro episode was coming, we #8217;ll see when that pans out. I also wish they would add non-factory paint colors at say 4 or 5*. Some of the cars only allowing a single base color is pretty lame

After spending a lot of gold to get a P1 to 3.75* in week 1 of McLaren event, my super card today finally got me the last dupe to take it to 4*! I figured I #8217;d get a different Epic McL dupe sooner , but happy it shook out this way. My senna is already up to 660pi tho so can #8217;t decide if I wanna leapfrog it with the P1 or leave P1 in the low 600s. Nice problem to have #128523;
Even before this I liked to run it on the Super upgrade events. 585 good enough for super brake easiest path until I pushed my Senna high enough to auto race it.

I would say don #8217;t worry about rare or epic, once you get something to 4* it almost doesn #8217;t matter. If you #8217;re leaving spin card chips on the board in upgrade events because you can #8217;t get past the car blocking that path, you #8217;re dragging out the time to get the spins for the cars you want. If it #8217;s just the last car you can #8217;t beat just take the spin chips and quit. Half the supers are rares it seems. GTR amp; Huracan my faves among the non epic moderns, if I didn #8217;t have either Senna or P1 at 4*, I #8217;d upgrade one of those. I opted for the Diablo over 911 for retro but unsure if that was the right choice- better speed, but slow turns amp; super unforgiving on missed turn timing. Fall behind and you can #8217;t early gas your way out of trouble. Miura over 904 for classic. A bit more forgiving than Diablo on early gassing.
FS is such an epic lottery. I haven #8217;t even gotten my first Skyline II! Should I #128557; or #128514; ?

Yeah at the time it felt like wasted gold, because it would be the next McL event (1 year?) before I could advance it more. Happy sort of that they started adding it to the odds of other spins, but figured long odds, 1-2% for any epic, which played out. P1 was my 2nd epic, and I picked up 2/3 of the rest (and dupes of some of them) before I hit on this P1.

Did you not have any stashed gold for the McL event? 1700g more would have guaranteed your senna to 4*? Trick in the P1 is to mash and hold at the right time to launch. For me it #8217;s the instant the 2 countdown shows. Before it grows. The needle bounce just goes below the green, I think I #8217;ve hit that once. The rest of the time I #8217;ve missed late (needle heading towards green) or jumping the gun (heading out of the green zone). That happened a lot in my experiments hyper focusing on the area where numbers show; the box shade changes and maybe there #8217;s a ghost 2 showing. I #8217;m not sure if those times I miss early I trigger on that or just jumped the gun with countdown timing in my head. Other cars I #8217;ve started a strategy of mash and hold and do the countdown like a conductor 3 and 2 and 1 AND (releasing with the AND). I miss 1/4 as goods, 1/4 too much gas, but the half perfects good enough for me, except for really big margin Rivals races with slow rise super tame launchers like focus and 2008 M3, Huracan, etc. where you can work out a tap frequency that hovers 80-100% of the time in green zone.

Right but seems odd that you #8217;d be jealous of only a 4* P1 amp; Senna given the amount you spent on a 5* F1. If I only had 10k in gold I would have just taken all the McLs to 4*, since most/all of the game is lt;650? Pi
Don #8217;t feel bad, I paid 400g for the double down a few days ago #128541;

Early gassing or and late braking you can do it, the timing is tough but in desperation moves you can try it. Practice on ep112 to see how early you can get away with, and even if the opponent is not in the right spot you can imagine where an opp car would get squished or pushed in a tight race. If you are getting outside passed on turn bay3 or DD3 and the extra perfect gas won #8217;t get you to or close to a full double or single boost, if you have a slider/wide turner (Charger RT, F1, Capri, many classic muscles) especially, wait til the outside passer is just ahead level with their door or rear bumper, and early gas into their side, this will slow their acceleration past you, maybe send them into the wall/curb and scrub their speed more than yours. If you have a good turner and on the turn outside, with a perfect or slightly early turn, you can clip their nose as they #8217;re trying to finish their wide/slidey turn, cause them to slide/waggle and lose speed. If a slider gets the inside track ahead of you, as they slide wide, and you corner a tighter line, sometimes you can boost into their tail and cause a spin out. Bay1 if you managed perfect launch and brake, sometimes gassing out a wheel width early gets you almost the same turn line, you #8217;re nearly full double boost already, so can dodge trouble trying to push you from behind.

Congrats maybe? I don't have one yet, but guessing like a Focus, requires a different/special driving style. Based on Superscherge on Bay2 apparently you can boost right up to and through turn 2 with a no lift. You can probably do a microlift (pickup just in time for the perfect brake and no hesitation right back on the gas) to pick up a half boost tank with minimal speed loss. If you perfect launched amp; braked Bay1 you can probably jet out super early without scrubbing the wall too. I would suggest on DD attempting to see how close to a microlift you can do on the turns without sliding out. On a Focus you need to get just past turn midpoint to avoid crashing into walls, but maybe a Skyline2 is even more special on that. The early turn exits might be able to make up for the lack of speed, especially on DD. South Beach I think you're toast regardless of any tactics, but maybe some experimentation time trials can determine what is the best time you can manage (e.g. SB1 w/ perfect launch amp; brake, gas out super early, maybe SB2 you can very early gas out too, might be worth more than the half boost from perfect gas), and then plan accordingly for Rivals or whatever.

On my iPhone Xr, launch zones register perfect. iPad mini4 it's a guess o matic just like you experience. On twitchy launchers I just mash the pedal and attempt to time the countdown, if I do 3 and 2 and 1 AND (releasing on the and) most of the time it'll land on the good or perfect. Work out your own timing. On the jumpy throttle cars sometimes if you release early it blows through into the slow zone, so be ready to backstop with a light tap before it flies out of the good zone. Perfect gt; good launch gt; too much gas gt; slow launch. If you normally start a given car with rapid taps to hover the needle, just shade it on the low side of the green. The stats bars are meaningless. I find SB most useful for gauging true speed. After your boost out of turn 2, it usually gives you a quick look back if you're way ahead, or you can see where the opp car is if you're behind or close, you can tell if your gap or lead is widening or shrinking in flat straight runs.

I was replying to that exactly. The needle and the color zones are laggy on some devices, but what it says on the text (and how your boost circle looks after) is what really happened. Rapidly rising needle with a lag, shows dead in the perfect zone but says over gas. Rapidly falling, shows dead perfect, but says good. Falling needle showing red might be perfect. Rising needle showing yellow/good might be perfect. So depends on how fast the needle was moving and which way, shades what it shows vs what actually happened on laggy devices. Unless you're OK with too much gas, usually better to shade on the conservative side. Bounce the needle half into the green zone. The higher you push it, the higher odds it's actually in the red. It's not quite a craps shoot, it's very systematic in the tendencies, but difficult to control for on the twitchy launchers since the needle moves so fast.

BTW, same deal on the brake and gas zones, on the iPad mini I feel I have to brake and gas ever so slightly sooner than I do on the Xr. 1 or 2 line stripes / 0.05 second ahead, because if I go exactly by the visual I'm into the next zone (too late). E.g. if I hit gas when my tire is touching both the red and yellow zone, I get perfect. If I hit brake when my tire is between the stand up perfect marker and the red zone, I get late brake even when the tire is still on yellow. Another interesting glitch is DD2, sometimes the brake zone is compressed, and pretty much all you see is the stand up marker with all the stripes piled under it. That stand up marker is still correctly indicating the perfect brake point, just pretend all the other yellow stripes are there, it will still give you a good/great brake as usual.

Mr Tiberius Bach drives street classic, so short of having TWO street classics in the mid 500s, only way to dominate this is burning wrenches? I guess it #8217;s not that hard to get two street classics to the mid 500s, and you can always stash wrenches. What would be your preferred approach?

I was just wondering if future events in Ep3 have more of the same, classic street being Bach #8217;s specialty, in which case leveling up a classic street over burning tons of wrenches makes sense. I guess I can pick the easy path all the way through episode and decide how best to mop up dominate afterwards?

BTW in case you didn't already realize or tried using it, shallow turns like Bay2 and SB3 are brake optional in some cars, some you can microbrake (barely lift before gassing again), or half brake for other cars, if you need the half boost. I find trying to nail the perfect brake and adjusting the gassing time works best for me (vs late braking and perfect gassed exit) If you are somewhat to a lot behind in these races, you can pick up a lot of ground as the AI usually tries to do a half decent brake/gas regardless of the turn. BUT, you will be exiting with a huge speed differential so on sloppy turners, 1. you may be riding outer curbs or hitting walls or posts and lose some or much of that speed 2. you ride the inside curb passing if you car is a better turner than the AI, maybe losing some speed, but often still passing them 3. you hit them square on the bumper on the exit and lose all your speed, like a billiards shot. This happens a lot if both cars are equal turners. The later you early gas the more control your car has on the exit (the less likely a square on bumper hit), but of course the less your speed advantage. So what you do depends on your car, how far ahead the AI is, what car they have, etc. You can also do this even if you are ahead, to make sure they don't catch up. In Rivals, locking down the win is more important than the +25pts of another perfect brake. I need to learn this better, as I've been burned multiple times trying to squeeze few more points on a perfect gas. GT40, Countach, other "slow" cars have decent final speed, so if you try (and especially miss early) that perfect gas, you've lost both the speed AND the half boost. If you got pushed out from behind on Bay1, if the opp car got ahead, return the favor at Bay2. Imagine a straight line from where your car is pointing, and that is where you will be going for the first 1/4-1/2 second out of an early gas. You might clip their nose or push them sideways into the curb, scrubbing their speed, and be ahead after you break contact. Freestyle driving as I call it makes the game a lot less boring. Doesn't guarantee more consistent wins, but as you get better at it gets you out of jams and lets your recover from mistakes, while introducing opportunities for other mistakes. And for some outlier cars as superscherge puts it, introduces possibilities for atypical strategies. Whenever I run my Focus in Rivals now, I push the edges of early gas wherever I can, and anywhere past the turn midpoint it sticks those turns, way more time than you would gain from the half boost of a perfect gas (boost is super pathetic on a focus). I used to run Focus against only +20pi in Rivals, but now I dare to try the mid +30 range not just against other Focus. Sometimes I'm surprised by the winning margin, but I still don't dare vs +40pi. Those final straightaways in a Focus feel like forever, waiting/dreading for the opponent to blow by.

Dang those are fast times. I wonder if lap times vary by platform. I have a Z06 up at 648pi running bayside PPPO (the last OK I was testing jetting out early turn 3) .. 9.897, 21.03, 28.696, 42.926... double boost about 1.5 sec out of turn 1, double boost around where the b/w guard rail stops after turn 3. Someone videoed a straight perfect run on a Turbo 2002 (running on PC) \~570pi and they got a 43.3s Bayside time and on iOS with mine near 600pi I could barely get the low 44s range with straight perfects. I've since pushed it to 640pi should test again, but I don't think I ever go sub 43s, even being \~70pi higher.

If you have a crystal ball and can predict which epics are coming up in spotlight in a reasonable time frame upgrade that :) On a more serious note, short of a known spotlight coming up, 4\*ing an epic is a superslow time frame, fraught with random luck or lack thereof. One maxed out epic early is good just to blast through generic upgrade events, non-restriction story races, and lead the pack in class upgrade events (with 3 races the easiest class brake or intake upgrade path is half done- you just need one more high PI car in the class to finish and get the part. Try and go with one classic and one modern each class to lead their respective packs and finish at least one path in class upgrade events. One high retro (any class) to dominate the generic upgrade events, gets you those parts up to 3x faster (3 per day not just 1). Then fill in other class retros (except muscle) to dominate their class events. Of the cars you have, take your chargerRT as high as you can, it's a keeper if you can 3\* and then 4\* it. Your ZL1 may get stuck at 585pi so if spotlight events come up with Charger Hellcat jump on that and try and get it as close to 4\* as you can while the event runs. Mustang GT and CTSV are serviceable muscle commons if you get tired of waiting to 4\* a rare. Likewise Cuda Hemi is an OK common classic muscle. Personally on the modern supers I like the GTR over the Porsche. The Huracan is not bad and the spotlight car this week, so try and hammer on the spotlight event to see if you can get one to 3\* or higher. Spotlight 3 there are always some spotlight chips on the first dot so run that and quit immediately once you got your chips, even if you can't beat any of the cars in the event. If the first car in an event is up to 40pi higher than your cars, take a crack at it anyway. 2 cars (or 3 if you hit collector level 15) = 6 or 9 tries to get 1 win in spotlight, and you can collect the stuff immediately behind it. If you get through with tries left over move on to the next race after collecting your stuff. Same for class upgrade events, the class spin chips are worthwhile even if you can't finish a given path. Sports if your 720 gets stuck at 2\* too long, if the Cayman hits 3\* it's a good common. The 570s is OK too. Sports classic yes the stingray 427 is good. Street modern yes m3, get it as high as you can on spotlight. Classic the escort is OK. Turbo 2002. Skyline. Somebody tested all 3 and got times within about 0.2sec on all for a track (maybe South Beach?) so not a lot of separation. To collect tuning kits, spam on Ep1-1-2. If you win all 3 at max difficulty that's 5 challenge cards, all at 400 tuning units each (guaranteed), and \~300CR to use them. As you get to higher upgrade levels you will run out of CR (and even here you're running a 100 deficit).

could you tell by the slow motion photo finish who won? there have been some where i had to wait for the you lose or you win to show up to know... is 0.001 less than 3 inches (\~5cm, probably about the size of lead you can spot with a photo finish). which porsche 911 is this? i've leveled up a diablo but not sure if that was the right choice for retro super for me, it's not the greatest turner and so pretty unforgiving once you make a few mistakes. when initially trying stuff out i found the retro 911 a little slow on straight runs. but probably more balanced capabilities.

I would go with the results database on one of the tabs on that google doc. Not opinions, run times on tracks. You can enter your own race results there, and there are a few track/car combos that have zero entries. Filter on a given track, filter by time (e.g. lt;52.5 sec on SB), you can see cars that run atypically fast for their PI. Some of it is just being in the hands of a good driver, but you can mentally compensate, an extra perfect is maybe 0.2 sec?

Sometimes the last 0.25\* on a rare car takes forever to get. If they were equal I would say 720 but the Viper is already 4\*. So you can level it up way higher for the time you're still waiting for your 720 to hit 4\*. If you've got too many cars needing parts and tune kits or CR to level up competing for resources then you can sit tight until you sort out those other cars where the preferences are less ambiguous. But it could be a day, a week, a month (or more?) before that last 3\* copy or 3 2\* copies of a 720 drop for you.

If you quit and restarted a run, you may have picked up one of the items without successfully running the line segment behind it, so the item is gone, but the line segment wouldn't be colored in (e.g. if actually fully finishing the route colored the lines differently after the fact, that would make it clear - maybe that is something we can request in an update). Just like beating an opponent doesn't get you a check until you beat the last opponent on a route in the same run, you need to do the same for all the line segments, even though they don't have checks showing. Your only choice may be to run and finish the routes all over again, until you clear it. So run topmost route all the way through. Check completion after. Run the middle. Check completion. Run the bottom, check completion.

Totally agree on that, pick to suit your driving style/tendencies. Go to Ep1-1-2, if you run the bottom route you get one race each track. The opponents may change as you run through one car vs when you take the other through, but you'll get a sense of which tracks are more troublesome. Bayside is kind of in between, so maybe you pick the car that does better on 2 of 3 tracks for you.

Pushing it with +40pi, on Bayside3 nearly full up with double boost, opt to early gas out. Boost mid tunnel, then waiting forever for the slo mo sequence - Countach lands, rips through the final flat, and.... YOU WIN! Bay2 I sent it into the curb with a super early gas, but near double boost full I should have late braked or even earlier gassed turn 3 more than I did since it caught up thru the turn. Classic 911 has OK final speed, a bit faster than P1. Boosted about the same time but it was a bit ahead at that point... ah well you win some you lose some #128557;

Congrats. It #8217;s well balanced but like the Boss 302 not super fast on the long straights. But 4* opens the door to upgrading the heck out of so you can auto race almost everything. Personally I liked the miura more, so my 904 sat at 511pi forever until I got my miura up to 4*

But even on a good turning car like the 08 M3 you can force the issue if you like. Cars in FS totally made of Kevlar because despite all the action, everyone comes out spotless. #128536;
Personally I like the GTR more, but given how far behind it is, in star progression, run with the Huracan unless you hate how it drives. Superb and easy perfect launch, Ok speed, but slow turns.

WRITING.TITLE: Design District Bully 2 : Z4, Eat Some Sidewalk

WRITING.TEXT: Sloppy run in a Charger Hellcat. Missed the perfect brake on DD3, at 1.1 boost. Perfect gas would leave me at 1.6, a single + later single would likely come too late, so early gassed to send the Z4 up the sidewalk. Boosted while it was up on the sidewalk to ensure it stayed behind.
Yeah make do with what you have when the star gap is too big.

Missing in front is often Ok too. Sometimes the AI in trying to dodge the hit will slow enough that despite a bounce off a wall you #8217;re ahead, and with a single boost in hand you can reaccelerate for a win. Done that at DD3 too. Timing I usually shoot for is sometime when my nose is near their rear wheel. You #8217;ll regain speed on the early gas and they #8217;re mid braking, so you #8217;ll end up level or a bit ahead while applying the crunch.

Two possible strategies. 1. Your Huracan is already at 4\*, you can just crank up the PI until you can autorace everything in sight. In the meantime it helps you clear at least part of the Super Brake Upgrade event = more spins = more chances at a Modern Super you really like. 1. In the meantime if you race it occasionally, you may get better and understand that car's tendencies. 2. You find a Super Modern that you like how it drives more, max that out at 575, and drive it so well that it punches above weight. You can probably take out 595-605pi cars with good runs, but of course you mess up a race it may take wrenches or rerunning the whole event (whereas if you had a Huracan at 615-625 you're guaranteed auto-race wins in those races). Take all candidate cars to the max of their generic exhaust PI, or maybe right up to the point where they're waiting for a 2 Super exhaust upgrade. Then you can get a sense of how they perform at higher PI. I sent my recently 4\* Huracan (got it up because of the spotlight, usually I run P1 or Senna for modern super, long shot of getting those now that McL event is over, and even then they max out at 585 for 3\*) up against a P1 about 10pi lower and lost 2 races in a row to it. But the P1 is especially good- other races I tested Huracan on (vs Superveloce, Retro M1, Diablo) it held it's own against slightly higher PI, but I couldn't swing +20pi yet. Because the throttle is so gentle, you should be able to over the needle in the green zone for a perfect launch like 90% of the time. At least on iOS, super light rapid touches, you can inch up or inch down or hover the position based on the rate of touches. I use pointer finger, since it moves faster than thumb, and you have the 0.3 second where it shows perfect or good launch to switch to thumb throttle for the race if that's how you like to run. Most all the Lambos seem to have a slow hanging turn, I haven't quite worked out the best option for optimizing that beyond attempting straight perfects, but their acceleration speed may make up for a lack of boost on an early gas out of a turn. I've found also they don't seem to like to turn much on gassing out of corners, so you can't go too early, else you're heading into a curb or wall. Another thing to try is the intentional late brake. Since it hangs forever waiting to finish the perfect turn, maybe the Lambos brake super well (overbraking normally?), and running late brake on the first half of the turn will shorten net time of waiting. You give up half a boost doing that, but Lambos with their decent speed and acceleration may make up for that. Maybe to wean your way into that, work your way towards braking as late as possible in the perfect zone, and see if your misses (late brakes) affect your average track time much. If that works, try later and later braking to see what you can get away with. Most cars very late brake you're barely holding on, totally pointing the wrong way when the perfect gas zone comes up, and you blast through the gas zone so fast it's hard to manage a great or perfect gas. You might stand a chance with the Lambo's super slow turn end to nail the gas timing.
I #8217;m just long winded. People at work say that too #128540;
Just 5 more cards and you should get one ;)
No clue. Where will it show and how do you know? Maybe they #8217;ll stick something in messages? My guess is it might be something like a free class or premium card.

It #8217;s what the boost meter is showing. Full up I call 2, 1 is just the inner circle. The decimal is approximately what portion of the circles are filled. Each perfect gas or brake will get you a half circle worth of boost. Running down a leg of a track you #8217;ll pick up another half boost. So as you are entering or exiting a turn you can work out whether in a best case scenario you have any possibility of completing a single or double boost, either from the turn, or early enough to use on that leg. Being at 1.6 boost perfect exiting a final turn means that effort for a perfect gas is likely wasted (the second boost only ready near the finish line) you #8217;re better off trying to crunch the opponent, or at least exiting the turn w/o crashing ASAP, to keep or increase your lead, or minimize falling behind more. Every fractional second you are off gas, you are slowing.
Why not gold for CR. you worried they will come with some limited time only cars on releasing retro episode and you #8217;ll not have enough?

Hah. Did you ever get that excess challenge card redemption issue fixed? Else spotlight and other dupes are the only way you can get tuning up to max out PI of your cars for rivals amp; such. I #8217;ve taken all my 4* commons to the max tuning for level 1. Until FS I never appreciated how lumpy/streaky small count stats were. On the Huracan event I pulled 5 straight, while on this M3 one I made runs up to 6 amp; 8th cards for pulling my first two.
Why not send a second into that gap when it happens. Sometimes I have a DOH moment and directly send the bait car into a race

Yep, got them all to 461pi, even the ones I hate running. So now when the bait car pulls a smaller gap I #8217;ll run one of those. As I get excess CR I #8217;ll push all of those to the max of level 2 The other strategy is to use a slug as the bait car when you have big pi gaps in the clusters. That one you race straight up with the +15-19pi car it pulls up as an opponent. Even in cars you hate you can do better but sometimes you can #8217;t be bothered. Of course there are times when the brain is on autopilot and you leave one car un run in the cluster. Or you run the bait car directly early on. So now I sometimes have a 2nd bait car same PI or 5-10 lower as a sort of back up.

Based on that the opp PI bump is approx 400pts/125pi Roughly 3pts/pi So yeah the differential is much bigger for the pi gap #8220;difficulty #8221;, 20 pt per pi. But how many missed perfects do you think you could get away with on the 911 run and still win? I #8217;m thinking one late brake or early gas (outside of the intentional/ useful ones on Bay2 or SB3) But I #8217;m guessing you could win the +19pi against a slow launcher GT40 blindfolded (beeps on the launch, the chittering before the brake zones) and just roughly knowing the timing for the gas zone. Maybe I exaggerate a bit, but it #8217;d be cool to try. Maybe I #8217;ll test on ep1-1-2 one of these days.
That can work if the gap is lt;80-100pi. After a few times of mistakenly going up against a +130pi opp (that pesky 100s digit) I #8217;ve decided to fill in any gaps gt;60 with bridge cars

P1 GTR by a long shot, if you can work out the launch. Centenario has great amp; easy perfect launch and great speed, but horrible at turning, takes forever to complete a turn perfectly, and not that great with handling early gas. On the countdown (at least on iOS), the INSTANT you see the 2, hit and hold down gas. Work out your own timing depending on your reaction times and platform. Needle will bounce off the top, right to the bottom of the green zone and back up. Watch which way needle is going if you miss. If it's red still heading down you missed late. If it's heading up and out barely out of green you jumped the gun. If it's near the top you missed super horribly. If it's just below the green zone in the good range (there's a tiny sliver where the needle bounce is changing direction), don't adjust anything. Maybe 2-5% of the time you'll get those, but unless your timing is consistent to 0.01 second every single time, you're more likely to mess up your other launches than fix those near misses by trying to go a bit earlier or later.

WRITING.TITLE: Car Suggestions for each type/era: Update to include Personal Rankings
WRITING.TEXT: The car suggestions page now has room to add your personal rankings within each era/class, and an on the fly calculation of average rank of all users. [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1uliYI-CDk5NIgJuuyzogk0N2oiKE6zMzyoxRBVAtmzM/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1uliYI-CDk5NIgJuuyzogk0N2oiKE6zMzyoxRBVAtmzM/edit?usp=sharing) No worries if you haven't experienced some cars enough to pass judgement, just put some personal identifier at the top for the column you fill out, and you can rerank at some future date. At least in each class put in what you think of as best and worst (for worst put in the max # = # of usable cars within the era-class).

Just rank it higher if you like it. I personally rank based on how much Pi differential I can give to other cars and still win in Rivals or story. Viper launches and turns well, but lacking in top speed.

Did I sound mad? Just stating the obvious (vote accordingly if you think the rank is wrong). I saw many disagreements with the main ranking column, which only had possibility of one value per car. So added user entries to see what other cars people thought were good, and if many people thought alike would give more weight than a single person's judgement.

Hard to remember a scale across a big list, and some people will spread scale and others compress. I think that gives more weight to the wide scale rankers. Will test adding personal column of comment next to ranks, to see if that messes up the avg calculator. So retro cobra r (rank 1, best AND worst in class-era)in a personal comment column ( next to your rank) #8220; Slightly worse than modern Cobra R #8221; I do wish over time the race database gets filled out more. More objective. currently many unreported car/track combos, and then that becomes a kind of regression calculation (currently have simple graphs) Look up from graph Avg expected time for a 500-550-600pi car on track X is such. And then one can easily deduce if they are doing avg or better with their given car.

I would stockpile unless you're short on CR/ until/unless they add GT40 to the super classic spins. In the end probably not gonna make a huge difference if the drop rate on the GT40 stays lt;2% as usual for epics. Running the class upgrade events you'll get tuning w/o CR which will tilt your balance even more. I think at some point it may be worth using gold for CR, of course leaving enough for epic double downs. Or if you think they'll bring back a GT40 for gold spins (at 140g a pop)
Any reason you #8217;re sitting on so many CR? You probably have like 100+ tuning kits in each category.

Those bars are deceiving/inaccurate at the least, although I think qualitatively they reflect somewhat the devs intended characteristics for the car. Viper is great at turns but slow at the top end. You #8217;ll notice at high PI speed amp; accel went up a notch. Consequently, you wouldn #8217;t expect the car to hold as well thru turns. Makes sense. But don #8217;t rely on those bars to set expectations for manually run races whether in story or rivals. The race times database on the car recommendations Google sheet stickies in this reddit you can see (and enter your own) average/good times for car/track/pi. There are lots of gaps but you can see what cars have low times for their given Pi.

Well over 100 days waiting for this car, and expecting to need 100 more, the car of my dreams (or nightmares?) finally arrived. I think I will try out no lifting every turn on every track in this sucker, and see if it pulls off some epic tricks, or epic wrecks.

Fun w/ my new Skyline V-Spec II. In DD just like on every other track, it can only no lift the shallow turns, so after turn 1 I decided to try and micro brake (brake and immediately gas) all the rest of the turns. A bit less of a mess, but a mess nonetheless. Closer than I expected though, I just needed a full boost about a second earlier.

Trade off I think on the waiting is that you are now much further behind. After my turn 1 crash opp woulda been halfway down straight before I was up to speed to boost. I went from near dead stop to a static trailing I think mostly due to the boost. These crash restarts are kind of variable so I think a better test of your theory is a turn 1 split time in a slow car off a perfect launch. 1 boost the instant the single boost is ready. 2 boost at the time you think of as up to speed. Z06 was my first epic and first epic to 4*, so I #8217;m ok with it. Middling on all fronts but not weak on anything. Mustang GT feels similar to me. 914/6 I feel are pretty weak in general. You run a bad start to a race and they #8217;ll catch up tho. And their boost is weak. Driving one Bayside in the lead, I think I had a double blasting uphill and got passed in the post jump slo mo.

720 is a bit slidey, better than F1 amp; 570s, all are very capable if you can hit at least perfect/great combos. In rivals DD I #8217;d blown most everything up to turn 3 vs a GTR around +30pi so I tried to nail its rear from behind and missed wide right. I think I #8217;d been tuning my timing based on the 2008 M3 where if you wait too long on the early gas you hardly swing wide and don #8217;t even make contact. One thing I #8217;d noticed is the AI car seems to jump big gaps when you miss turns from in front, eg on Bay1 or 2. I would think getting to the turn first off a perfect launch and brake vs a slow starter car, early gas on Bay1 would increase the gap, but the look back cut they #8217;re right on my tail. Same thing after a double boost downhill to Bay2, sometimes I feel on perf brake/early gas ( to get a bigger lead) the trailing AI is way closer than expected, vs a double perfect where on the look back the AI is barely arriving at the turn. Whereas from behind esp on Bay2 the early gas definitely closes the gap. Still haven #8217;t worked out a best strategy on Bay3 when I get inside passed in the lead up to the turn. Even when on the look back after turn2 the AI is a few lengths behind, it often gets inside track, despite my hitting brake zone first, and perfect braking. Maybe a slightly late brake?

Have you been able to replicate 47s on SB? I don #8217;t have a Spyder but most of my 570pi cars can only swing around 48.5 give or take. Never even 47.9s. What platform you playing on? Wonder if it makes a difference. Someone posted a video of a Turbo2002 568pi on bayside doing 43.3s (Android maybe? Lots of in your face fireworks on every perfect turn) and mine at 640pi barely goes sub 44 even with straight perfects (iOS).
What #8217;s your next best super, its PI, and time on SB ?(nearest .1 sec or so.. ). I #8217;m assuming in your 510pi Spyder it #8217;s high 57s, like 57.8 or 57.9?

For muscles try retro Cobra R as opp. GTO 2nd choice. Modern Cobra R 3rd choice. Sometimes Boss 302. Have gotten burned a few times vs modern Cobra amp; Boss so I #8217;ll only take those with my stronger muscles, or shrink the PI diff. 35pi is pretty doable. 40 you gotta be sharper amp; get a weak opp. I feel like difficulty gets steeper gt;45pi For sure for sure if you are trailing, early gas on SB3 and Bay2 is more reliable than getting perfect gas for the extra half boost. The win is way more important than the extra 25pts (reminder to self). Only try for the double perfect if you #8217;ve got a big lead entering the turn. You gotta learn how much a given car can stand early gas though. Most cars on SB3 amp; Bay2 once you #8217;re 2/3 of the way thru the turn you can gas early without eating much or any curb. Some you can even stay floored on the gas all the way thru. Practice on Ep1-1-2. One of each track. On DD it #8217;s harder. All turns are the same 90 deg. The key is what to do on DD3. Decide on the fly after you braked - a perfect brake gets you a half boost. My rule of thumb is if you #8217;re not gt;0.25 or 1.25 boosts after the brake, even a perfect gas taking you to 1.75 is little help since you #8217;ll get to 2.0 boost late in the backstretch. So there I #8217;ll gas the earliest my given car can handle w/o jumping the curb.

Take your charger as high as possible and try amp; live with it until you get stuck. I had a 300sl get stuck at 3.9* for 1.5 months, along comes a Stingray spotlight, I dominate daily figuring the occasional sport classic dupe chips from that will eventually advance my 300sl. spotlight pops my stingray from 2* to 4*, and it #8217;s not until 2 weeks later that my 300sl hits 4 *. My gut feeling is that advancing whatever 4* you have will get you your favored cars advanced faster than just sitting and waiting. If you can almost finish the muscle brake event, one path has classic 5000 chips = 1 spin 2x per week (even if you quit, you keep the chips). The classic chips in intake are only 3000, so it might take you almost 2x longer. Trade off is using up CR amp; tuning kits and parts.

Congrats, based on the title and SkylineII being spotlight this week I had assumed it would be that. A 4* epic is still useful for auto racing at cranked up Pi, and once you learn its tendencies you can make the most of the situations when you actually have to race the Viper. Great launch, great turning, slow top speed. Try and nail the launch amp; early perfects to build up a big enough lead to hold on for the finish. Especially on the final turn gas, work out whether you are helped much by that half boost of a perfect gas (or the 1/3 boost of a great gas if you miss). Having 1.6 boost on the homestretch is often worse than having 1.1 boost but gassing out of that final turn a half second early.
With one to go you should probably make it by weeks end. Hey you could make it your top epic too so 2 shots at +19 max. Or other tactic, top of a low cluster before a giant Pi jump.

Like others have said, wait until your tire smoking stops at the least. Sometimes it doesn't do the cutaway to external view but based on past runs in the same car you can guess where you're not sliding much any more. On Bay1 I wait also until my front wheels are no longer sharply angled/drifting (from the external view), from behind car view, about when it looks like you wouldnt hit the wall until halfway downhill if your straightlined your current orientation. Maybe a 3-4 count out of the gas zone. None after Bay 2 unless I so messed up start amp; Bay1 (too much gas + late brake, or good brake + good gas) that I'm only at 1.5 boost midway down hill. Then I'll burn the single and try and decide, brake amp; early gas (grippy car), or try and double perfect Bay2 and use single boost (for bad sliders where early gas is all sorts of mess, especially if you're outside car). Bay 3 I usually kick it about where I feel I'm somewhat straight, midway thru the wall black/white markers. Earlier as possible if it's a 300sl, 35thSuper Sport, Boss302, which often go sideways on landings. Those if my double boost isn't ready within 2 seconds out of Bay3 I'll do single single. Basically if you see/hear your own tire screeching, wait a beat until it stops before kicking the boost in. There are always some exceptions, e.g. DD3 if you successfully shoved opp up the sidewalk, I tend to boost now the instant I break contact, a few times waited a sec too long and they dropped back down in front and boosted away. Maybe the different outcomes are due to the opp boost state rather than what I did, but anyway, I figure it can't hurt to be somewhat in the way when they try and boost either way.

Awesome. I #8217;m convinced now there #8217;s a platform boost/bias. Android definitely faster than iOS for a given car amp; pi, half a second for same PI, or same time with 50-70 lower Pi. But as long as the shift is constant within platform no big deal. I guess it messes up the implications of the race database somewhat ? Who #8217;d a thunk. I guess I need to add a platform field in there.
